text_run.content: Zilliz Cloud offers private access to your cluster through a private link. This is useful if you do not want your cluster traffic to go over the Internet.

To enable private client access to clusters on Zilliz Cloud, you must create an endpoint in each of the subnets within your application's VPC. Then, register the VPC, subnets, and endpoints with Zilliz Cloud so that it can allocate a private link for you to set up a DNS record mapping the private link to the endpoints.
The following figure demonstrates how it works.
This guide walks you through setting up a private link for a cluster.
Make sure the following conditions are met:
You have signed up for Zilliz Cloud.
A cluster has been created. For information on how to create a cluster, see
Zilliz Cloud offers you an intuitive wizard to add a private link. On the
Setting up a private link is project-level. When you configure a private link for a cluster, it applies to its neighboring clusters in the same project deployed in the same cloud region.
Select a cloud provider and region
To create a private link for a cluster deployed in an
, select the region that accommodates the cluster you want to access privately. For more information on available cloud providers and regions, see

Once you have created a private link in a project, it applies immediately to its member clusters that have been deployed in the specified region. For those clusters that undergo maintenance then, such as scaling or patch-fixing, the private link applies to them after maintenance.
Before creating a VPC endpoint, you need to have a VPC on your Amazon console. To view your VPCs, do as follows:
Find the VPC of your desire and copy its ID.
Subnets are sub-divisions of your VPC. You need to have a subnet that resides in the same region as the private link to be created. To view your subnets, do as follows:
Change the current region to the one specified for creating the private link.
Find the subnet of your desire and copy its ID.
on Zilliz Cloud. To create a subnet, see
Create a Subnet in Your VPC
Copy the command generated at the bottom of the
dialog box on Zilliz Cloud, and run this command in your Amazon CloudShell to create a VPC endpoint.
The returned message is similar to the following:
In the returned message, copy the ID and
name of the created VPC endpoint.
hen, enter the VPC endpoint ID in
After verifying and accepting the VPC endpoint you have submitted, Zilliz Cloud allocates a private link for this endpoint. You can view it on the details tab of your cluster.
Before you can access your cluster via the private link allocated by Zilliz Cloud, it is necessary to create a CNAME record in your
zone to resolve the private link to the DNS name of your VPC endpoint.
Create a hosted zone using Amazon Route 53
service. Create a hosted DNS zone so that you can add DNS records to it.
Private Link allocated by Zilliz Cloud for the target cluster.
Description used to distinguish hosted zones.
In the VPCs to associate with the hosted zone section, add your VPC ID to associate it with the hosted zone.
Create an alias record in the hosted zone
An alias record is a type of

record that maps an alias name to a true or canonical domain name. Create an alias record to map the private link allocated by Zilliz Cloud to the DNS name of your VPC endpoint. Then, you can use the private link to access your cluster privately.
In the created hosted zone, click
, and select Route traffic to as follows:
Select the cloud region in the second drop-down list.
Enter the name of the endpoint that has been created above.
Select a cloud provider and region
To create a private link for a cluster deployed in a Google Cloud region, select
, select the region that accommodates the cluster you want to access privately. For more information on available cloud providers and regions, see

Once you have created a private link in a project, it applies immediately to its member clusters that have been deployed in the specified region. For those clusters that undergo maintenance then, such as scaling or patch-fixing, the private link applies to them after maintenance.
Obtain a Google Cloud project ID
Find the Project ID of your desire and copy its ID.
Enter this ID in Google Cloud Project ID on Zilliz Cloud.
Before creating a VPC endpoint, you need to have a VPC on your Amazon console. To view your VPCs, do as follows:
Find the VPC of your desire and copy its Name.
To create a VPC network, see
Subnets are sub-divisions of your VPC. You need to have a subnet that resides in the same region as the private link to be created. To view your subnets, do as follows:
Click the name of the VPC of your desire.
Find the subnet of your desire and copy its name.
For your convenience, you are required to set an endpoint prefix in
so that any forwarding rules you create will have this prefix.
Copy the command generated at the bottom of the
dialog box on Zilliz Cloud, and run this command in your GCP CloudShell to create a Private Service Connect Endpoint.
In the returned message, copy the endpoint name listed on
Then, enter the copied name in
After verifying and accepting the preceding attributes you have submitted, Zilliz Cloud allocates a private link for this endpoint. You can view it on the details tab of your cluster.
Set up firewall rules and a DNS record
Before you can access your cluster via the private link allocated by Zilliz Cloud, it is necessary to create a CNAME record in your
zone to resolve the private link to the DNS name of your VPC endpoint.
To allow private access to your managed cluster, add appropriate firewall rules. The following snippet shows how to allow traffic through TCP port 22. Note that you need to set
to the name of your VPC.
gcloud compute firewall-rules create psclab-iap-consumer --network $VPC_NAME --allow tcp:22 --source-ranges=35.235.240.0/20 --enable-logging

in your GCP console and create a DNS zone.

On the details tab of your cluster, click

View the guides to connect your database via endpoint
Why does it always report a timeout when connecting to the private link on
A timeout usually occurs for the following reasons:
record exists, you can ping the private link as follows
If the IP address of the VPC endpoint has been resolved correctly in the output of the ping request, the
If you see the following, you need to
No or invalid security group rules exist.
You need to properly set the security group rules for the traffic from your EC2 instance to your VPC endpoint in the
console. A proper security group within your VPC should allow inbound access from your EC2 instances on the port suffixed to your private link.
command to test the connectivity of the private link. In a normal case, it returns a 400 response.
command hangs without any response as in the following screenshot
, you need to set up proper security group rules by referring to step 9 in

Two security groups must be configured: one for the EC2 instance, which must allow traffic on the port associated with your private link, and another for the VPC endpoint, which must permit traffic from the IP address of the EC2 instance and target the specified port number.
when I ping the private link on GCP?

Set up firewall rules and a DNS record
